sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with noisy data
message_1:
The problem is: 
Solve the following system of linear equations with noisy data using Gaussian elimination:
\begin{equation*}
x + y + z = 6.3 \\
2x - 3y + z = -4.4 \\
3x + 4y - 2z = 5.5 \\
\end{equation*}
where the coefficients of the equations are known exactly, but the right-hand side has a measurement error of $\pm 0.2$ units for each equation.
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using Gaussian elimination, we first write the augmented matrix:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 1 & 1 & 6.3 \\
2 & -3 & 1 & -4.4 \\
3 & 4 & -2 & 5.5 \\
\end{array}\right]
$$

Now, we perform Gaussian elimination:

1. Subtract 2 times the first row from the second row, and 3 times the first row from the third row:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 1 & 1 & 6.3 \\
0 & -5 & -1 & -16 \\
0 & 1 & -5 & -13.4 \\
\end{array}\right]
$$

2. Divide the second row by -5, and add the second row to the third row:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 1 & 1 & 6.3 \\
0 & 1 & 1/5 & 3.2 \\
0 & 0 & -24/5 & -16.6 \\
\end{array}\right]
$$

3. Multiply the third row by -5/24, and subtract 1/5 times the third row from the second row:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 1 & 1 & 6.3 \\
0 & 1 & 0 & 2.5 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 3.45 \\
\end{array}\right]
$$

4. Finally, subtract the third row from the first row, and subtract the second row from the first row:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 0 & 0 & 0.35 \\
0 & 1 & 0 & 2.5 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 3.45 \\
\end{array}\right]
$$

The solution to the system of linear equations is approximately $x \approx 0.35$, $y \approx 2.5$, and $z \approx 3.45$. However, since there is a measurement error of $\pm 0.2$ units for each equation, the true values of $x$, $y$, and $z$ might be slightly different.
